questiontext.text:
Solve the following using reciprocals

  1. \( {@a_num@} \div \frac{{@a_den@}}{{@a_num@}} \)
  2. \( {@b_coeff@}x = {@b_rhs@} \)
  3. \( \frac{{@c_num@}}{{@c_den@}} x = {@c_rhs@} \)
  4. \( {@dec1@} \div {@dec2@} \)

(a) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] [[feedback:prt1]]
(b) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] [[feedback:prt2]]
(c) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] [[feedback:prt3]]
(d) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]] [[feedback:prt4]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

Dividing by a number is the same as multiplying by its reciprocal.

  1. First, replace division by multiplication with the reciprocal.
  2. Then simplify the expression.
  3. Finding the value of\(x\) is like dividing the value after the equal sign by the reciprocal of the coefficient of \(x\)
  1. \( {@a_num@} \div \frac{{@a_den@}}{{@a_num@}} = {@a_num@} \times \frac{{@a_num@}}{{@a_den@}}\)
    \(= {@ta_a@}\).
  2. To find the value of \(x\) in \( {@b_coeff@}x = {@b_rhs@} \), first find the reciprocal of the \(x\) co-efficient then multiply it by the value after the equal sign.
    \(x= \frac{1}{ {@b_coeff@}} \times {@b_rhs@}\)
    Therefore, \(x = {@ta_b@}\).
  3. Finding \(x\) in \( \frac{{@c_num@}}{{@c_den@}} x = {@c_rhs@} \), we have:
    \(x = \frac{{@c_den@}}{{@c_num@}} \times {@c_rhs@} \)
    Hence, \(x = {@ta_c@}\).
  4. \( {@dec1@} \div {@dec2@} = \frac{{@d1@}}{{@10@}} \div \frac{{@d2@}}{{@10@}}\)
    \( = \frac{{@d1@}}{{@10@}} \times \frac{{@10@}}{{@d2@}}\)
    \(= {@ta_d@}\)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

node.description: Checks for the correct computation of the expression

truefeedback.text: You have simplified {@a_num@} with the denominator of \(\frac{{@a_den@}}{{@a_num@}}\). Remember division does not cancel out instead you multiply {@a_num@} by the reciprocal of \(\frac{{@a_den@}}{{@a_num@}}\).

node.description: Checks for incorrect value of x

truefeedback.text: You multiplied {@b_rhs@} by {@b_coeff@} instead of multiplying it by the reciprocal of {@b_coeff@}

node.description: Checks for incorrect value of x

truefeedback.text: You failed to take the reciprocal of the coefficient fraction \(\frac{{@c_num@}}{{@c_den@}}\)
